body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History: 'Adventures in Superstring Theory' (Wednesday) Dr. S. James Gates Jr., a theoretical physicist who specializes in the mathematical study of string theory, will present a lecture at 7 p.m. Cocktails and refreshments are available; must be 21 or older. Central Park West and 79th
title: Spare Times

body: Nobody knows a man better than his ex-wife. So Moe Prager's ex-wife, Carmella, is wise to this veteran private eye, accepting the fact that no matter how many times he marries, his first love will always be Brooklyn. ''When you die, they should just bury you right here, under the boardwalk,'' she tells him in HURT MACHINE (Tyrus, $24.95; paper,
title: CRIME; Last Exits in Brooklyn

body: THE bicycle swung wide left under Alexander Barouh as he furiously pedaled to the end of his 500-meter sprint, bringing gasps from the crowd standing only a few feet from his front wheel. ''Don't steer!'' some spectators in the Lower East Side bar shouted. As he struggled to steady himself, a large red arrow spun behind him, tracking his progress
title: SPOKES; Racing in Bars, Going Nowhere Fast

body: ENCASED in pouches with a small speaker attached to the outside, iPhones dangled from belts and wrists. They emitted dings and chatters as some 60 people began strolling along the High Line on Wednesday night. The sounds slowed or speeded up according to the pace, and they evolved every block or two, sometimes evoking vibraphones or soft electric
title: Marching to Their Own Drummers

body: Outdoor performances can be the worst. For this one, a jackhammer almost drowned out Jerry Stiller's opening lines: I think that I shall never see A poem lovely as a tree. The parks department had enlisted Mr. Stiller to promote MillionTreesNYC, a 10-year program to add that many trees to the five boroughs. So Mr. Stiller was mugging and hugging on
title: CITY ROOM; Seeking a Million Trees, With at Least That Many Tales

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com; Twitter: @jimdwyernyt
body: To hear Michael R. Bloomberg tell it, a judge put a dangerous criminal back on the streets because she couldn't be bothered to make a simple phone call. ''It's not a lot of work to do to protect the public,'' Mr. Bloomberg said Wednesday. His implication was devastating: the judge, Evelyn Laporte, was at least partly to blame for the death of a
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; As the Mayor Lays Blame on a Judge, a Court's Chaotic Context Is Lost

body: Most of us, while visiting the New York Transit Museum, will not care too much that in the 1930s large coiled tubes containing liquid carbon tetrachloride were used as fuses to protect the city's subway system from short circuits. Many of us approach this subject so lightly that we might think a label on an electrical contraption -- ''Edison
title: MUSEUM REVIEW; Stand Clear Of the Ghosts

body: GORDON--Trudy. Beloved. wife of the late George; loving mother of Adam and Donna, Alan and Fuji; adoring grandmother of Rachel and Michael; devoted sister of Irving and the late Martha, Henry and Willie; cherished aunt of Bernice and Roberta; treasured great-aunt of Janice, Laurie, Cindy and Amy. She will live in our hearts forever. Services 9:30
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GORDON, TRUDY

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday criticized the Brooklyn Criminal Court judge who allowed the man accused this week of killing a police officer to be released from custody without bail in an earlier drug case. Speaking at a news conference on Wednesday, the mayor said the reason the ex-convict, Lamont Pride, was free from jail in recent
title: CITY ROOM; Bloomberg Chides Judge After a Killing

body: Despite his being wanted for a shooting in North Carolina, the man accused of killing a police officer in Brooklyn on Monday was twice released from jail in New York this fall because the authorities in North Carolina declined to have him extradited, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday. The New York police had arrested the man,
title: After Officer's Killing, a Focus on a North Carolina Warrant

body: Frederico Farina, a creative director for fashion brands, recalls waking up every morning last summer in his 21st-floor apartment in Brooklyn Heights and gazing across the river at the new Frank Gehry-designed apartment tower in Lower Manhattan. Its rippled stainless-steel facade reflected the sun, making it shine like a beacon. ''One day, my
title: THE APPRAISAL; Living in a 76-Story Work of Art, and a Symbol of Rebirth

body: When Olga and Alexander Vartsaba won the green card lottery and moved from Russia to the United States in 2002, they believed their luck had finally changed. What they never expected was to be living nine years later in an apartment in Coney Island, Brooklyn, with no furniture -- not even beds for their three young children. The Vartsabas have had
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Giving Their Children a Place to Lay Their Heads

body: Updated, 4:58 p.m. | Five construction workers were rescued from a five-story apartment building under construction in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, that collapsed on Tuesday afternoon. One worker was in critical condition, the Fire Department said. There were no workers missing. The building, at 2929 Brighton Fifth Street, near Neptune Avenue, fell
title: CITY ROOM; Worker Dies After Being Rescued From Building Collapse in Brooklyn

body: COHEN--Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Paula. Loving father of Jonathan (Rita), and Kenneth (Barbara). Cherished grandfather or Meryl (Joseph), Jacqueline (Jon), Jared, Marc and Suzanne. Adoring great-grandfather of Dylan and Hayley. Devoted brother of Helen and the late Augusta, Etta, Irene, Pearl, and Rose. Dear uncle. Services today 1pm at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COHEN, ABRAHAM

body: Most of the time what passes for excitement on 74th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is figuring out which neighbor will get to feed a lurking stray white cat. The New York City Marathon, which electrifies so many other streets in the neighborhood as it comes through year after year, always bypassed this sleepy,
title: Thrills Take Detour to a Sleepy Block

body: The New York Police Department, already saddled with corruption scandals, saw its image further tainted on Tuesday with the conviction of a detective for planting drugs on a woman and her boyfriend. The bench verdict from Justice Gustin L. Reichbach in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn stemmed from acts committed in 2007 by the defendant, Jason
title: Detective Is Found Guilty of Planting Drugs

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Museum of the City of New York: 'Kevin Roche: Architecture as Environment' (Friday through Thursday) New York sites connected to the 89-year-old architect Kevin Roche -- among them the United Nations Plaza, the Ford Foundation building and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, for which he designed more than 45 projects --
title: Spare Times

body: HALLOWEEN SPOOKTACULAR No one would deny that high school can have distressing, scary and even hair-raising moments. But the fearsome classroom episodes about to unfold in Jersey City have nothing to do with neglected Latin declensions or forgotten math theorems. And those zombies at the desks? They're not just sleep-deprived adolescents. Welcome
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: As the corruption trial of a New York police detective wound down on Thursday afternoon, the detective's lawyer portrayed him as anything but a dirty cop: the only blemishes on his 14-year career, the lawyer said, were a car accident on the job and having worked for a charity without permission from the department. In fact, the lawyer said, the
title: In Drug-Planting Trial, Defense Says Officer Is Not Corrupt, but a Reformer

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Merchant's House Museum: Candlelight Ghost Tours (Friday and Saturday) Tours every half-hour from 6 to 9:30 p.m. of what some consider the most haunted house in Manhattan. 29 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 777-1089, merchantshouse.com; $25; $40 (includes servant's quarters); $13 for members. Morris-Jumel
title: Spare Times

body: BOONTON, N.J. -- When dusk descended here last Sunday, and the forum on domestic violence was over, some 200 people carrying candles marched up the hilly street to where Nazish Noorani had been killed exactly two months earlier in a shooting the police said had been set up by her husband. By the time of the vigil, Ms. Noorani's two young sons were
title: After Arrest of Man in Wife's Death, a Custody Fight

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com Twitter: @jimdwyernyt
body: Because Yvelisse DeLeon of Coney Island was due at an interview for a bartending job on the evening of Jan. 25, 2007, she spent part of the afternoon getting herself ready. That process included a trip to Downtown Brooklyn. ''I went down here to get color for my hair,'' Ms. DeLeon, 35, testified this month in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. ''Jay
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Story Of Drugs And the Police

body: Among the 275 tenants filling four million square feet of leasable space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- now in the midst of its biggest expansion since World War II -- are any number of industries that do not easily evoke the imagery of ''On the Waterfront.'' These are businesses where fine art is warehoused, where antiques are restored, where
title: BIG CITY; One Day, Maybe, Artisanal Train Cars

body: WASSERMAN--Bernice S.,85, of Brooklyn Heights, died October 14. Dearly beloved wife of Dr. Bernard, cherished mother of Harvey and Kim and Andrew and Donna; loving grandmother of Jake and Sarah; beloved aunt, cousin and friend. Graduate of Erasmus High School and Hunter College, she worked for Science Magazine. She was an avid supporter of the arts
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WASSERMAN, BERNICE S.

body: FINDING a home with room for a family can be hard enough in New York City. But when Barden and Catherine Prisant decided to sell their house in the East Village because a tall building was to go up next to their beloved backyard, their challenge grew by several degrees of difficulty. In addition to uprooting their 8-year-old daughter, the move
title: LIVING IN | PROSPECT PARK SOUTH, BROOKLYN; Houses Are Few, but Not Far Between

body: Over the 30 years that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz have owned part or all of the Mets, their other business interests had remained largely out of view. Even as Wilpon's profile in baseball grew, he and Katz were rarely referred to as anything more than real estate moguls who gave generously to charities. The trustee representing the victims of the
title: Breadth of a Business Empire

body: STEP into the tight entryway of Noah John Gellner's compact studio apartment on the Upper West Side, and try to squeeze past the everyday bicycles perched on their hooks. There is his road bike -- a titanium rocket from Colorado -- and hanging below it, a customized mountain bike, also titanium. Leaning against that bike is another that belongs to
title: SPOKES; Ride This Bike? Nay. This Beauty's Made for Framing.

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Center for Jewish History: 'Moses Mendelssohn and the Legacy of the Enlightenment' (Sunday) ''A Continuing Conversation: Moses Mendelssohn and the Legacy of the Enlightenment,'' a symposium on the 18th-century philosopher and scholar who is considered to be the founder of modern Jewish thought, is planned in
title: Spare Times

body: SEVEN years ago Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self magazine, was looking for a way to get excited about exercise again. She had been running almost daily for years, but a marathon had left her with painful shin splints, and she was tiring of her routine. ''I needed a gentler way to work my body and also something to combat the boredom I was
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Three Times the Effort, but Not the Cost

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com
body: Cosmopolitan parochialism is woven into the collective soul of New York. Do ya miss the city, a Queens councilwoman asked me in 1998 when I was working in Washington. She supplied the answer before I could open my mouth: ''Of course you do!'' Well, right, I suppose that's true, then and forever. But when work brought me back here in the summer of
title: GOTHAM; What the City Didn't Lose After 9/11

body: Ana Ramirez, 35, of Coney Island swung her metal detector over the sand just off the Coney Island Boardwalk in the shadow of the Wonder Wheel ride. -''People say that storms sweep a lot of sand away, so it's a good time to look for things on the beach,'' Ms. Ramirez said as she walked on the beach a few days after Tropical Storm Irene lashed the
title: For Beachcombers, The Tropical Storm Whipped Up Hopes

body: It may not be the most well-known aspect of the New York Fire Department, but there is a large subset of firefighters who surf. Many of them hail from the Rockaways and the south shore of Long Island, and many manage to work in firehouses in southern Brooklyn and Queens, which makes it easier to catch a few waves before or after work. The
title: For Police and Firefighters, City Is Surfing Hub

body: -It may not be the most well-known aspect of the New York Fire Department, but there is a large subset of firefighters who surf. Many of them hail from the Rockaways and the south shore of Long Island, and many manage to work in firehouses in southern Brooklyn and Queens, which makes it easier to catch a few waves before or after work. -The
title: For Police and Firefighters, City Is Surfing Hub

body: NEW YORK CITY UNICYCLE FESTIVAL Most of us spend a good part of our lives navigating the world on wheels: three when we're little, two when we're older, and of course the ubiquitous four. But only the truly skilled can get around on just one. Those extraordinary talents will have their day -- actually three -- this weekend, when the New York City
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: THE journey from an Ohio theme park to Brooklyn has been long and difficult for 48 wooden horses, who today are scheduled to trot, canter, leap -- O.K., be wheeled -- from the Dumbo studio of Jane Walentas, the artist who spent over 20 years overseeing their restoration, to their permanent home, a carousel in Brooklyn Bridge Park. It opens on Sept.
title: A Ride With Head-Spinning Views

body: A scuffle broke out at an amusement park in Westchester County on Tuesday when a group of Muslims there to celebrate the end of Ramadan were told that women could not wear their head coverings on certain rides, park officials and witnesses said. Fifteen people were arrested. The Muslim American Society of New York had arranged the trip to Playland
title: Park's Rules On Scarves Are Cited In a Melee

body: David Clark sat in an ambulance for hours late Saturday night in front of the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn. Mr. Clark, who is 48 and relies on a wheelchair because of diabetes and a leg injury, was late to receive his medicines. But he still had not even been admitted to the armory, which was a designated shelter for patients with special medical
title: For Some Medical Evacuees, Safety Brought Its Own Difficulties

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was a ubiquitous scold, appearing on camera four times in 24 hours to tell grizzled urban dwellers that, yes, they had to take the threat of dangerous weather seriously. He was a decisive crisis manager, demanding that 370,000 people evacuate their homes long before the first raindrops fell. And he was a reassuring
title: This Time, Mostly Praise for the Mayor

body: They took a corner in the school's gymnasium, finding forest green city-issued cots for themselves and their four children. They unfolded their blue city-issued fleece blankets, stamped with the city's official seal, opened their paper cartons of water and settled in for the night. For Kevin and Sharon Harvey, the decision to seek shelter at an
title: School Gym Shelters Evacuees From Irene

body: Tropical Storm Irene swept through the desolate streets of New York on Sunday, flooding low-lying areas and leaving millions of homes without power along the Eastern Seaboard as it continued on to New England. Most New Yorkers emerged from their makeshift bunkers to find little of the widespread devastation the authorities had feared. But the
title: New York Spared Brunt of Storm; Suburbs Hit Hard

body: It was as if one huge new and very bad neighborhood appeared overnight in New York City. Zone A. This area, once housing sought-after properties with waterfront views, now deemed at risk of flooding, became blighted with red marks on a map -- from Battery Park to Coney Island to Staten Island's south beaches -- as Hurricane Irene approached with
title: New Yorkers Flee by Taxicab, Bus and Wet Feet, or Not at All

body: Dorianne Alecia Green, the daughter of Alda Grace Anthony of Richmond, Va., and Philip F. Green of Brooklyn, was married Friday evening to Marc Antoine St. Fleur, a son of Marie C. Souffrant of Brooklyn and Justin St. Fleur of Gonaives, Haiti. The Rev. Easton G. Grant, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at the Inn at New Hyde Park in New Hyde Park,
title: Dorianne Green, Marc St. Fleur

body: As she and other customers picked the shelves bare on Friday afternoon at a supermarket in Breezy Point, Queens, Jackie Fede said she planned to abide by the official order to evacuate before Hurricane Irene hit. But she had yet to convince her mother to go. ''They're saying the ocean's going to meet the bay,'' said Ms. Fede, 25, a nursing student
title: Ordered Out, Some Residents Begin Retreat From Hurricane

body: New York officials on Saturday urged residents in evacuation areas to leave immediately as Hurricane Irene started to pummel the North Carolina coast. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made that plea outside Albany as he met with National Guard members being deployed to Long Island to help with the storm. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued his warning at a news
title: With Storm Near, 370,000 In City Get Evacuation Order

body: Whether patriots of the American Revolution, opera stars or a man who can lift and bend things with his hair, all kinds of extraordinary people are the focus of events around the city this weekend. In August 1776 the Battle of Brooklyn was fought on part of the land that now makes up Green-Wood Cemetery. On Sunday, to commemorate the battle's 235th
title: Weekend Miser

body: With Hurricane Irene threatening a full-force hit, New York City on Thursday ordered the evacuation of nursing homes and senior centers in low-lying areas and made plans for the possible shutdown of the entire transit system. The governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut declared states of emergency, and in one county in South Jersey, a
title: As Hurricane Approaches, Getting Ready For the Worst

body: Visitors sometimes winced a little when they walked into one room at the home of Dr. Robert Megna, a physician in suburban Dallas. He and his wife, Bridget, lined the walls with surgical saws, forceps, tonsil slicers and wood-handled cranks for pulling teeth. ''People could just spend hours in there, looking at all the different pieces,'' Dr. Megna
title: ANTIQUES; Misguided Moments In Medical History

body: BOONTON, N.J. -- After his wife had been shot to death on the street and he had been wounded, Kashif Parvaiz told the police here in her quiet hometown in New Jersey that three men had accosted them and, before opening fire, called them a name that is offensive to Muslims in America: ''Terrorist.'' That prompted detectives to treat the case as a
title: Husband Admits He Set Up Killing Of Wife in Street, The Police Say

body: It may not be this summer's most gripping beach read, but a civic organization's new 27-page report should bring smiles to New York's swimmers and sunbathers. The report, by the century-old organization New Yorkers for Parks, says the city's municipal beaches have shown a ''vast improvement'' since its last survey two years ago, with beaches like
title: Report Finds 'Vast Improvement' at the City's Beaches

body: WINNIE-THE-POOH BIRTHDAY BASH Few 90-year-old celebrities can claim legions of fans under 12. Probably even fewer could sit unperturbed through a party with those clamorous admirers. Then again, most nonagenarians aren't Winnie-the-Pooh. On Saturday the New York Public Library will hold a 90th-birthday celebration for that eminent bear: not
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: The digital mailman stomped through the rains early this week to deliver questions from almost-newlyweds, the tennis-obsessed and a reader with a food allergy. I put on my writing gloves and tried to help. As ever, you may send questions about restaurants in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com. Or find me on Twitter: @samsifton. Q. My
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; Food for Beer Lovers, Tennis Lovers and Lovers, Period

body: Steve Ross says he was happy to take his bialys out of New York. But no one was taking the New York out of his bialys. In 2001, Mr. Ross, the owner of Coney Island Bialys and Bagels, received an invitation to demonstrate authentic city baking at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival in Washington. Organizers supplied the mixer and an oven. Mr. Ross
title: CITY ROOM; Familiar Oniony Scent Will Soon Waft Away

body: For Shel Wallman, a co-editor of the Jewish Sports Review, the searching question, if rather high profile, was not uncommon: should Ralph Branca, historic goat, get to join the magazine's list of official Jewish athletes? Wallman, whose publication has come out six times a year for 14 years, weighed the competing information. Branca had been raised
title: Pondering the Meaning Of Branca's Jewish Roots

body: Ravi Greene can tell you how to get anywhere in New York City by transit -- like the beach, on the 6 train. ''The 6 goes elevated from Whitlock Avenue to Pelham Bay Park,'' he explains. ''And at Pelham Bay Park, you can transfer for a Bx29 or a Bx12 -- the Bx12 to Orchard Beach.'' Ravi has drafted elaborate proposals for expanded bus service in
title: Giving Children on Autism Spectrum A Different Kind of Rail Connection

body: Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History: 'Brain: The Inside Story' (through Sunday) The days are ticking down to see this exhibition, an interactive display that blends technology, history and neuroscience. Timed tickets are available hourly beginning at 10:30 a.m., with the last ticket sold each day at 4:30 p.m.; the museum is open
title: Spare Times

body: Pop Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. American Idol Live (Sunday and Monday) Every year ''American Idol'' trots out its finalists -- this year it's the Top 11, with Casey Abrams, Naima Adedapo, James Durbin, Stefano Langone, Jacob Lusk, Paul McDonald, Thia Megia, Haley Reinhart and
title: The Listings

body: Museum of the City of New York: 'Whose Park is It? Financing and administering new york's new parks' (Tuesday) Creating and maintaining green spaces during a budget crunch is not exactly a walk in the park. An urban oasis designed today is very different from one designed in the days of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux; you need only look at
title: Spare Times

body: Woody Guthrie saved paperwork documenting his peripatetic life, from utility bills for New York apartments to fliers protesting shanty demolitions in Seattle and lyrics for folk songs performed at a Los Angeles radio station. He and his family put some of the artifacts in scrapbooks, but that did not fend off damage over the years. The glues and
title: ANTIQUES; Saving Scrapbooks From the Scrapheap

body: IS there a creature as imaginative or as indefatigable as the city child in search of a place to play? New York would seem to have been designed for everything but youthful frolic. And, to be sure, it can hold great perils. Yet from generation to generation, ever since children sang ''Ring Around the Rosie'' and ''London Bridge Is Falling Down,''
title: The City As a Jungle Gym

body: When it showed up unannounced in April, the neighbors stared, goggle-eyed. Some compared the scene to one in a classic Stanley Kubrick film. ''The neighbors started gathering around it like it was the monolith in '2001,' '' said the Rev. Jeanne Person, an Episcopal priest who has lived in a century-old pocket of Flatbush, Brooklyn, for 11 years.
title: In an Early 1900s Neighborhood, a Glimpse of '2001'

body: It's the thick of summer, and the heat can make you just a bit crazier than usual. But how do you cope when even your therapist abandons the stifling city? McNally Jackson Books comes to the rescue for the sixth year in a row with ''The Shrinks Are Away!,'' a night of readings hosted by Susan Shapiro, an author who describes herself as a
title: Weekend Miser

body: WANTAGH, N.Y. -- Aretha Franklin isn't letting medical problems sideline her anymore. At Jones Beach Theater on Wednesday night she let fly a voice with its power, range and improvisational spirit fully alive. Her songs were about the strength and the value of a good woman's love, freely given, and about the healing powers of faith. She sang about
title: MUSIC REVIEW; A Fount of Soul, Full Throttle and Unbowed

body: Spare Times Museums and Sites Asia Society and Museum: 'Ai Weiwei -- New York Photographs 1983-1993' (Friday through Sunday, Tuesday through Thursday) A display of more than 200 photographs taken by Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and activist who was recently released from detention in Beijing, will be on view through Aug. 14. Museum hours: Fridays,
title: Spare Times

body: AARONS--Gwen, Beloved daughter of the late Bernard and Toby Aarons. Loving sister of Mark (Karen), Brian (Mimi) and the late Spencer. cherished aunt of Grant, Brady and Manoj. Highly accredited Systems Engineer for Depository Trust Co. Lover of all old movies. Services 1pm today at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave.,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths AARONS, GWEN

body: Jose Reyes was back in a familiar role Monday afternoon, penciled in as the leadoff hitter and shortstop on the lineup card. The setting, however, was different. Reyes was in Coney Island, Brooklyn, not Flushing, Queens, a stone's throw from the ocean instead of the No. 7 train. With a famous amusement park beyond the left-field wall, the beach on
title: A Rehab Game, And Reyes Is Ready

body: An ocean breeze drifts into the cavernous boardwalk store and settles inside like a sigh. Robert Suh, the 29-year-old owner of Coney Island Souvenirs, stands behind a small rack of vintage postcards, quietly scooping ice cream for teenagers and tourists. When a man walks off without paying full price, Mr. Suh just lets him go. A fight for 50 cents
title: At Summer's End, 7 Shops Will Vanish From Coney Island's Boardwalk

body: Pedro Beato vividly recalls the day he arrived in New York City from his native Dominican Republic. ''It was kind of a rainy day, I remember,'' he said. ''I was 13. Well, I was 12 and I was turning 13 the next month.'' Beato and his family settled in Woodside, Queens, a long toss from Shea Stadium, where his adopted hometown team, the Mets, played.
title: From a Long Toss From Shea to a Mets Closer

body: ZIMET--Sidney, former attorney, died 15 July 2011 in Brooklyn at the age of 102. He is survived by his three children, seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be on Tuesday, 19 July at 1pm at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ZIMET, SIDNEY

body: Coney Island, like many parts of New York, is just too big to get all abuzz when a civic crisis befalls one sector of the citizenry. It is so big, in fact, there could be two civic crises, as well as a hot-dog-eating contest drawing international media hordes -- all of which consumed Coney Island on Fourth of July weekend -- without getting much
title: Patrolling the Piers, but No Longer the 2-Ply

body: DWARFED by the soaring expanse of the long-vacant Kingsbridge Armory, a small group of bike advocates and Bronx residents strolled through the main hall recently and imagined a mecca of bicycling. Picture it: Over here, young BMX riders from the neighborhood perform tricks, spinning their bike frames and leaping over obstacles. Over there, racers
title: SPOKES; Bikers' Dream: A Bronx Velodrome

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: Architectural Tour (Sunday) Guided tour of the building that houses the Brooklyn Historical Society, designed by George Post and built in 1881. At 2 p.m., Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718) 222-4111, brooklynhistory.org; free
title: Spare Times

body: Catskill, N.Y. THE journey of 120 miles begins with a single stroke, but the Chinese philosopher Lao Tzu never swam in the mighty Hudson. David Barra peered over the edge of a pontoon boat drifting north in the steady current flowing past the Rip Van Winkle Bridge here. His friend, Janet Harris, had jumped in to swim south. Her arms slid deep into
title: Seven Days And 120 Miles To Go

body: IT was named for a European breed of bunny, whose wisdom was singled out in the Bible (''The conies are but a feeble folk, yet make they their houses in the rocks''). That is about as close as Coney Island has gotten to anything holy since it was converted from a barren spit of beach into a rollicking resort nearly two centuries ago. For four
title: The Strange Poetry Of Coney Island

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Q.An F.Y.I. item published on June 26, ''The Hotel Next Door,'' talked about fighting illegal short-term rentals through the city's Buildings Department and its Web site. Can you mention any other ways to fight these violations? A. Sure. Housing Conservation Coordinators, a nonprofit tenants' association that works with public officials to draft
title: F.Y.I.; More on Illegal Hotels

body: The Coney Island Boardwalk, opened in 1923, has inspired songs (The Drifters' ''Under the Boardwalk''), plays (Herb Gardner's ''The Goodbye People'') and fiction (Delmore Schwartz's ''In Dreams Begin Responsibilities''). Now, it is inspiring a question of Talmudic complexity: Can a boardwalk be called a boardwalk if it is not made of boards? Last
title: A Fight Over Keeping Boards in the Boardwalk

body: PIRATES OF THE HUDSON Forget the pirates of the Caribbean. In honor of this patriotic weekend, why not celebrate plundering and profiteering that took place closer to home? That idea has inspired Pirates of the Hudson: The Siege of Sleepy Hollow, a new festival at Philipsburg Manor, the restored Westchester County estate once owned by Frederick
title: Spare Times

body: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | He sat. He rapped. He handed police officers his demo tape. For nearly two hours on Tuesday morning, a man held court atop the traffic-light apparatus on 44th Street and Seventh Avenue, attracting a camera-wielding crowd and closing down three blocks of traffic in the middle of Times Square. At 11:12 a.m., the man climbed down
title: Well, That's One Way To Promote An Album

body: For a group of Chinese students spending this summer working in New York City, learning English was challenging enough. But learning Brooklynese? - that's Chinese for ''Fuhgeddaboudit.'' ''In university in Beijing, I learned British English, but the people here in Brooklyn speak very differently,'' said Li Xiaoshu , 23, an English-language major
title: CITY ROOM; Taking Orders in Something Like English

body: Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. body: When a guide informed me last year that the Green-Wood Cemetery was this country's second most popular tourist attraction in the 19th century, my first thought was: Those were better days. Catnip to history buffs and unabashed graveyard lovers like me, this 478-acre cemetery, fronted by a spectacular gothic arch, presents a stunning landscape.
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'THE SPOON RIVER PROJECT'; Good Place for Ghost Stories, Complete With Tombs

author: Lucy Ferriss's sixth novel, ''The Lost Daughter,'' will be published in February.
body: VACLAV & LENA By Haley Tanner 292 pp. The Dial Press. $25 Magic and magical thinking are the means by which the innocent can acquire power. This accounts for the appeal not only of the Harry Potter books but of adult-minded novels like Michael Chabon's ''Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay.'' Now Haley Tanner's first novel, ''Vaclav & Lena,''
title: Brighton Beach Magic

author: E-mail: metropolitan@nytimes.com
body: Enough already with the jazz. It's all over the city this month, what with the Blue Note Jazz Festival, the Undead Jazzfest and the Vision Festival: flitty, formless music that makes me want to bang my head against some bathroom porcelain. I had to go see Jake Szufnarowski and John Joseph to restore my
title: CITY CRITIC; Walk This Way: The Punk Tour

body: Talk about the reverse of not in my backyard! You'd never know it from the looks of the swimming pool, back porches, patios, makeshift garage, basketball hoop, parking lot for five cars and other suburban amenities squatting in the middle of a square block in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, but they occupy a 20-foot-wide corridor that is officially a
title: Forgotten Railroad's Land Makes a Great Back Porch

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum: 19th-century baseball (Saturday) A game of old-fashioned baseball, played according to 19th-century rules and in period costumes by the New York Mutuals and the Mineola Washingtons, is scheduled for 1 p.m. There will also be a demonstration of rounders, a precursor to baseball, and house
title: Spare Times

body: There are three million immigrants in New York City. When they left home, knowing it could be forever, they packed what they could not bear to leave behind: necessities, luxuries, memories. Here is a look at what some of them brought. SAM DOLNICK Jessica Lane, 29 CAME FROM Perth, Australia CAME IN 2010Ms. Lane, a dancer, outgrew her first pair of
title: Belongings

body: Beachgoers in bathing suits and the patter of residents speaking Russian: Brighton Beach on a hazy Friday in June. But there were also packs of police officers, some in uniform and some in plain clothes; a pile of discarded crime scene tape; several patrol cars; and a mobile watch tower, obvious clues that something had happened there.
title: A Family Mourns as Bathers Return to a Beach

body: One person was killed and four others injured during a wild shooting on a packed Boardwalk in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon, the police said. The shooting unfolded on a day when a mini-heat wave and a school holiday sent hordes of people to Coney Island and Brighton Beach, which were teeming with beachgoers -- many of them
title: Gunfire on a Boardwalk Kills One and Injures Four

body: Dear Diary: It was early April. I ambled through the reminiscent sounds of birds chirping, trees moaning, and winds blowing that welcomed me in -- I returned to Central Park. I arrived at the Chess and Checkers House on a cold afternoon to play a friendly chess game. The serene voice of the park, pleasing to my ears, was like a constant reminder of
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: The finer points of street handball, unlike other youth sports, are not learned from camps and coaches and clinics, but from pickup games on hot concrete courts around the city. There is no professional league to aspire to; college scholarships are rare. What amounts to a crowning event for New York's high school players, the individual
title: As Styles of Handball Clash, Two High-School Stars Are Disqualified

body: Classical Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music. Opera - 'Apollo and Dafne' and 'Clarence and Anita' (Wednesday and Thursday) A charged, fascinating double bill from Underworld Productions Opera juxtaposes two depictions of sexual aggression: Handel's 1710 cantata about a god pursuing a nymph and Ben Yarmolinsky's 2010 opera
title: The Listings

body: NOW that the glitterati, literati, digerati and hipsterati have been caught in the act of Ping-Pong, let's be clear: There is Ping-Pong, and there is table tennis. ''Everybody I meet either knows somebody or they themselves were at one point a terrific Ping-Pong player,'' said Marty Reisman, 81, the 1958 and 1960 United States Open table tennis
title: The Little-White-Ball Obsession That Isn't Golf

author: Susannah Meadows writes the Newly Released column for The Times.
body: VACLAV & LENA By Haley Tanner 292 pages. The Dial Press. $25. There comes a point in almost every relationship when you discuss the future. Where is this heading? Do you want to get married? Do you want to get married? Vaclav and Lena have had this talk. It has gone well. Vaclav and Lena are 10. In Haley Tanner's wonderful and wrenching debut
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Young Russians in Brooklyn Find Love, the Wonder Wheel and Then Life

body: Dressed in an orange Tony the Tiger vest and clashing red-on-black striped pants, and proudly sporting a mullet hairdo, Joe Mucha grasped ball after ball, achieving a score that reflected his years of training in the art of Skee-Ball. He made it look easy. Or as he would say, perhaps to the chagrin of others, ''skee-asy.'' ''That's why I've been
title: CITY ROOM; Pick a Pun, Grab a Beer, Roll a Ball: It's a Tournament

body: LEVITT--Mitzi. On May 28. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving and proud mother of Michael and the late Stacy. Mitzi leaves behind Maria, devoted friend and family member. A School secretary at the Rabbi Harry Halpern Day School of East Midwood Jewish Center. She was a supporter of charities and a treasured friend to many. Services Tuesday,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVITT, MITZI

body: Some may think that in summer, the city gets quiet, the traffic starts to die down a bit, and the brisk pace of the business suits slows to a saunter in a sundress. Some would be wrong. That's when the city gets rowdy with music festivals, parades, celebrations of art and food, and most of it at small cost. With so much going on, it's easy to let
title: Hot City, A Guide

author: Ariel Kaminer is on leave.
body: Last weekend, right about the time the rapture was supposed to be happening, I was ascending. Man, was I ever ascending. I believe I even shouted a few phrases invoking divine beings. It may have been the best 0.57 seconds of my life. This moment of bizarre ecstasy took place, as so many such moments have for so many people over the decades, at
title: CITY CRITIC; Coney Island Scream

body: A free concert series in Brooklyn promoted by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, will move to a new performance space in Coney Island after a dispute with neighbors around the park where the concerts took place for 20 summers. Mr. Markowitz announced on Monday that the Seaside Summer Concert Series, held since 1991 at Asser Levy/Seaside Park,
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Seaside Summer Concerts Moving to Coney Island

body: A pack of Newport Red cigarettes at a Midtown convenience store: $11.50. Drum rolling tobacco (rolling papers included): $13. The cost of getting caught smoking in the pedestrian plaza in Times Square: $50. On Monday, it becomes illegal to smoke in many outdoor areas of the city, including parks, beaches, pools, recreation centers and other spaces
title: Shrugs and Objections as Park Smoking Ban Nears

body: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul -- or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the
title: LIVING IN | SHEEPSHEAD BAY, BROOKLYN; Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure

body: In Coney Island, he was known as ''the rabbi.'' With his thick white beard and pointy mustache, muscled biceps and faded white tank top, Abraham Novitsky, better known as Rabbi Abraham Abraham, did not have a traditional congregation. His synagogue, people who knew him liked to say, was the beach, where he had been a fixture on the Boardwalk and on
title: Coney Island Bids Farewell To 'the Rabbi' of the Beach

body: Murray Handwerker, who transformed his father's Brooklyn hot dog business, Nathan's Famous, into a celebrated national fast-food chain, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 89. His son William confirmed his death. Nathan's Famous, at Surf and Stillwell Avenues in Coney Island, was opened by Mr. Handwerker's father and mother
title: Murray Handwerker, 89, Dies; Made Nathan's More Famous

body: THEY came for freshly shucked oysters and straight-off-the-leg prosciutto. They came for clacking vintage typewriters and old LPs repurposed as dog tags and bracelets. And they came, to the Brooklyn Flea in Fort Greene last Saturday, searching for meaning and connection in their rudderless lives. ''Flea markets proliferate a volume of goods needing
title: The Flea Marketing of New York

body: Where to find the fleas: THE ANTIQUES GARAGE 112 West 25th Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), Manhattan; Saturday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; hellskitchenfleamarket.com BK FESTIVAL IN CONEY ISLAND 3029 Stillwell Avenue at the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn; Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; bkfestival.com
title: Almost Everything Under the Sun

body: HALPER--Marjorie, on May 12, 2011, age 85. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Herbert L. Halper. Loving mother of Dale Cernuda (Jay Stern) and Meredith Gindi (Jack) and stepmother of Dr. Mitchell Halper (Della), Dean Halper and Dr. Bradley Halper (Susan). Adoring grandmother of Jan, Bryan, Shaun, Ryan, Blake, Joseph, Alyssa, Jillian and Jared. Cherished
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HALPER, MARJORIE

body: IN New York this summer the drive-in movie is thriving. Minus the cars. Technically, of course, it's not summer yet, and the weather has only just warmed up. Nevertheless, outdoor-film season is beginning this weekend. In the coming weeks, look for movies in the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens; in Brooklyn at Coney Island and
title: Starry, Starry Cinema (The Breezes Are Free)

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Historic Richmond Town (Friday and Sunday) The Staten Island Shakespearean Theater Company will perform a scene from ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' on Friday at 9 a.m. to celebrate the recent issue of a Gregory Peck commemorative stamp; the actor won an Academy Award for his role in the 1962 film version. The scholar Cindy
title: Spare Times

body: There were, of course, the joyous celebrations, the honking horns, cheering crowds and waving flags, as if war had been won and tyranny ended. But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope. As Americans streamed to the
title: A Mood of Triumph and Sober Reflection

body: London ''BACK then, people who had plans were idiots,'' Laurie Anderson said. She laughed. We were talking by phone one recent evening about what once appeared to be the end of days for New York City during the early '70s, when SoHo dawned. ''Like New York, we were all broke,'' she reminisced. ''We thought of ourselves as workers, conquering
title: ABROAD; When Art And Energy Were SoHo Neighbors

body: The walls in the basement of a building in Brooklyn's Chinatown were whitewashed, and boxes of cleaning supplies were stacked on the red tile floor. But beneath the disinfectant smell, the unmistakable odor of fish lingered as the flimsiest calling card of a former tenant. That tenant, Yong Hao Wu, sold fish until October for his Howei Trading
title: A Delicacy on Chinatown Plates, but a Killer in Water

body: Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. Michael Attias and Renku (Wednesday) Mr. Attias, a saxophonist, develops compositional fragments into compact expeditions in this working trio with the bassist John Hébert and the drummer Satoshi Takeishi. Their set will feature music from all three musicians. At 8 p.m., Barbès, 376
title: The Listings

body: GELBER--Sarah. Born November 6, 1923, passed away on April 25, 2011. Beloved wife of Hy, mother of Susan and Carrie, sister of Ben and Goldie, and loving grandmother of Zachary, Max and Nick. Sebby lived life to the fullest . . . her husband, family and dancing were her passions. Memorial service at noon April 27 at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GELBER, SARAH

body: CONEY ISLAND ROW HOUSE $415,000 BROOKLYN: 2830 West 17th Street (near Neptune Avenue) A three-bedroom one-and-a-half-bath 1980 row house with an open plan living area, a utility room, two-car parking in front, a backyard and central air-conditioning, two blocks from the Atlantic Ocean and the boardwalk. Chaohua Catherine Jin, Prudential Douglas
title: ON THE MARKET

body: It was not Edvard Munch's ''Scream.'' It was not Michael Jackson's ''Scream.'' And it was not even Howard Dean's infamous Iowa scream. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as a crowd witnessed on Wednesday, is apparently not one for screaming. On a day so foggy that the Boardwalk's towering Ferris wheel seemed to brush the clouds, Mr. Bloomberg traveled to
title: Everyone, Time to Scream! (Didn't Hear You, Mayor)

body: IT is a small case, really, easily lost among the thousands in New York City's courts. A retired schoolteacher named Nina Viola Montepagani, born in a hospital in Brooklyn in 1952, files a lawsuit to change her birth certificate. She wants to remove the name of her father. Or, at least, the man who said he was her father. Who acted like her father.
title: A Question Of Paternity

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society (Friday through Thursday) ''Magnet for the Masses: When Theater Was Paramount in Brooklyn,'' a conference on the cultural importance of the Paramount Theater -- now part of the downtown Brooklyn campus of Long Island University -- will feature discussions and performances on Friday from 9
title: Spare Times

body: As Jim Morrison sang, ''People are strange.'' And no one knows that better than the Coney Island Museum. Its Congress of Curious Peoples, also sponsored by the Morbid Anatomy Library, wraps up on Saturday and Sunday with a symposium featuring experts on the art of curiosities and a visit to Sideshows by the Seashore. ''The Fairground and the
title: Weekend Miser

body: TEITELBAUM--Rose Lea Harnick Died at 97 in her sleep on April 9th. A true matriarch, Rose was a touchstone for her family. "When one of my chickadees falls from the nest," she said cupping her hands, "I gently bring them back." Even in her later years, Rose provided a joyous welcome not only to family but friends of family, young and old. A high
title: Paid Notice: Memorials TEITELBAUM, ROSE LEA HARNICK DIED AT 97 IN HER SLEEP ON APRIL 9TH. A TRUE MATRIARCH, ROSE WAS A TOUCHSTONE FOR HER FAMILY. "WHEN ONE OF MY CHICKADEES FALLS FROM THE NEST," SHE SAID CUPPING HER HANDS, "I GENTLY BRING THEM BACK." EVEN IN HER LATER YEARS, ROSE PROVIDED A JOYOUS WELCOME NOT ONLY TO FAMILY BUT FRIENDS OF FAMILY, YOUNG AND OLD. A HIGH SCHOOL DROP OUT, ROSE WAS AN ENTHUSIASTIC READER AND A CURIOUS TRAVELER, ACCOMPANYING FAMILY TO MANY FOREIGN CITIES. AFTER 30 YEARS, AS A CORSETIERE AT SMALL SPECIALTY SHOPS, ROSE BECAME A POPULAR DOCENT AT THE LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM. THERE, UNTIL SHE WAS 94, ROSE LED AWED VISITORS THROUGH THE 6 STORY TENEMENT BUILDING, RECALLING THE LIVES OF ITS IMMIGRANT RESIDENTS. SHE ALSO VOLUNTEERED AT THE FAMILY CENTER AND CONEY ISLAND HOSPITAL. RAISED BY POOR IMMIGRANTS IN BROWNSVILLE, BROOKLYN, ROSE MOVED AT THE AGE OF 84 TO MANHATTAN TO BE NEARER HER SON, HERBERT AND HIS FAMILY. CALLING THE UPPER WEST SIDE A LEBEDIK PLACE, SHE REVELED IN LONG WALKS ALONG BROADWAY. THIS YEAR, ROSE MOVED TO ST. LOUIS WHERE HER OLDER SON, STEVEN AND HIS FAMILY RESIDE. IN ADDITION TO HER SONS, ROSE LEAVES DAUGHTERS, IN, LAW MARILYN TEITELBAUM AND RUTH J. ABRAM; GRANDCHILDREN: CAREN, AARON, AND NOAH TEITELBAUM; REBECCA WALLACE; ANNA KAYE; FOUR GREAT, GRANDCHILDREN: AMELIA ROSE AND STELLA ROSE KAYE, JONAH TEITELBAUM AND LEO WALLACE AS WELL AS GRANDCHILDREN'S SPOUSES: GORDON KAYE, LILA TEITELBAUM AND JOHN WALLACE. ON APRIL 13, FOLLOWING A PRIVATE BURIAL, A MEMORIAL SERVICE WILL BE HELD AT THE TENEMENT MUSEUM. IN LIEU OF FLOWERS, PLEASE SEND A DONATION TO THE LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM 91 ORCHARD STREET, NEW YORK CITY, 10002 C

body: Grand Prospect Hall has long held an affectionate spot in Brooklyn's heart, starting in the gaslight era of the 1890s when Brooklyn society ventured out of their elegant Park Slope brownstones to attend operas or other entertainment in the hall's gilded auditorium. In later generations, the hall was a vaudeville palace, a fraternal clubhouse, even
title: GREENWOOD HEIGHTS JOURNAL; Catering Hall's Plan For a Hotel Upsets The Neighbors

body: LET'S get this out of the way: The golf courses in New York City will never be confused with Pebble Beach, Bethpage Black or any of America's great public courses. If you want a four-and-a-half-hour round, meticulously manicured greens or even an unfailingly polite playing partner, consider going elsewhere. But if you appreciate the idea of hauling
title: Fairways Where Golf Becomes The City Game

body: Debbie Quintana-Stiefel knows it is time to expand her palette. Beyond the brown and deep-red lipsticks she carries, she must now add fuchsias and oranges and complementary foundations to satisfy her new customers. It is a fairly significant change she plans to make to cover the even more diverse complexions of the Brooklyn women she expects to
title: With Its Move to Coney Island, Flea Market Is Sprucing Up

body: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, may move one of his long-running concert series this summer because of opposition over the shows' noise and a proposal for a huge new amphitheater there. Seaside Summer Concerts, one of two free series presented by Mr. Markowitz, has been held at Asser Levy/Seaside Park, on the border of Coney Island
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Concert Series May Be Moving

title: Spare Times

body: Aid for Japan and Italy To raise money for Japanese disaster relief, an eclectic concert with something for everyone will be held on Thursday at 8 p.m. at City Winery, 155 Varick Street (Vandam Street). Tickets are $45 to $65: citywinery.com. There will be food and wine for sale. On Sunday, the restaurant Gemma, 335 Bowery (Third Street), will
title: Dining Calendar

body: For advice on how to catch a wayward snake in the Bronx Zoo, it seemed worthwhile to consult the city's own resident snake charmer, Serpentina, of Sideshows by the Seashore in Coney Island. She recalled how, some years ago, her albino Burmese python once got loose in her dressing room. Then Serpentina, sometimes known as Stephanie Torres, 34, of
title: Lost Cobra May Hide For Weeks, Zoo Says

body: When Daisy Eagan won a Tony Award at the age of 11 for her performance in ''The Secret Garden,'' she was so dazed, and so unfamiliar with the protocol of the ceremony, that when she left the stage and a crew member reached out to take the award from her, she thought that she had done something wrong and the honor was being revoked. ''I was like:
title: A Former Child Star Returns, With Wisdom

body: Two years ago, St. Joseph's Church in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, seemed to be headed for extinction. Attendance at Sunday Masses had fallen below 100. The 159-year-old parish's buildings were crumbling and its coffers were empty. Today, the scaffolding outside bustles with workers. Sundays draw more than 300 worshipers, many of them families with
title: NOW ARRIVING; Mexicans Fill Pews, Even as the Church Is Slow to Adapt

body: THE Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is inescapable in Bay Ridge, its lofty silhouette a constant presence on block after block. It would be understandable for someone like Susan Brown, a lifetime resident, to feel ambivalent about the bridge, since she recalls all the big changes that its construction in the 1950s occasioned for her family and friends.
title: LIVING IN | BAY RIDGE, BROOKLYN; You'll Notice There's a Bridge

body: Single-game tickets for the Mets will go on sale at 10 a.m. Monday at Mets.com and LosMets.com. Tickets can also be obtained by calling (718) 507-TIXX. On Tuesday, tickets will go on sale at the advance-ticket window at Citi Field; at the Mets' Clubhouse Shop on West 42nd Street in Manhattan; at MCU Park in Coney Island, Brooklyn; and on Long
title: Tickets for Mets Go on Sale Monday

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Alice Austen House (Saturday) The discussion ''20th Century Women in the Arts: Alice Austen and Jacques Marchais'' will focus on these two noted women associated with cultural institutions on Staten Island: the photographer Alice Austen (Alice Austen House) and the art collector Jacques Marchais (Jacques Marchais
title: Spare Times

body: This week brings questions about linguine and clams, critic bait and things you won't find in Detroit. As always, send your restaurant questions to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com. Q. Linguine with clam sauce. I'm on a two-headed quest: What should this dish have in it, and where should I go to eat it? For the former, to me, it's pasta, clams, salt,
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; The Linguine and Clams Conundrum

body: State Senator Carl Kruger, a powerful and at times controversial Brooklyn Democrat; a state assemblyman; and an influential lobbyist are expected to turn themselves in on Thursday to federal authorities in Manhattan on corruption charges, according to several people briefed on the matter. Mr. Kruger had been under investigation by federal
title: Brooklyn Senator and Assemblyman Face Corruption Charges

body: THE very mention of certain apartment buildings in New York evokes a genteel world of wealth, power and discretion. At the Dakota, 740 Park Avenue or 15 Central Park West a gantlet of daunting prices, white-gloved doormen, and in some cases Kremlinesque co-op boards, keep mere mortals from a nirvana of sun-drenched penthouses, richly paneled
title: 'It' Buildings Of The Other Boroughs

body: In a scathing critique of the Bloomberg administration's oversight practices, New York City's top fiscal watchdog has accused the city's main agency for economic development of allowing a contract with a construction company to balloon by tenfold in three years to nearly $74 million, and authorizing over $3 million in dubious payments. The
title: Comptroller and City Development Agency Battle Over Questionable Contract Costs

body: Sal Durante will always be a footnote to Roger Maris's 61st home run on Oct. 1, 1961. He does not mind the designation. He was 19, a Yankees fan from Coney Island who was driving a truck for an auto parts store when he leapt onto his seat at Yankee Stadium to catch the ball. After a variety of other jobs, he drove a school bus for 29 years until
title: At 61 Plus 50 Years, a Visit by the Lucky Fan

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society (Friday through Sunday) Handmade jewelry, clothing and other items will be sold at a Valentine's craft fair, co-sponsored by New York Creates, which assists New York City artisans; Friday from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. On Sunday at 2 p.m., some portrait subjects
title: Spare Times

body: SINCE becoming New York City's planning commissioner in 2002, Amanda M. Burden has presided over the rezoning of wide swaths of the city. Some changes have served traditional zoning goals -- encouraging higher density on commercial thoroughfares (particularly near transit hubs) while lowering density in residential neighborhoods. And some have
title: Who Says Zoning Has to Be Boring?

author: E-mail: oneducation@nytimes.com
body: They knew how the script was going to end. Still, on Thursday night, 2,000 students, parents, teachers and union officials filed into Brooklyn Technical High School, voicing their frustration for five hours. When the schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, opened her mouth, she was drowned out by people yelling (''Cathie's gotta go'' and ''Black is
title: ON EDUCATION; In Move to Close Low-Performing Schools, Rage at Foregone Decisions

body: There was the recently familiar annoyance -- at the buses that did not come, at the thigh-high stoops that had to be shoveled. There was the unmistakable beauty -- the snow-laden trees, the backdrops that Norman Rockwell could not have improved upon. And there was the nagging question: Is New York City the new Buffalo, where snow -- snow on the
title: The Winter New York City Seemed More Like Buffalo

body: MISHKIND--Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Mishkind, and mother of Michael, daughters-in-law Jeannie Jenkins and Judy Jablon, granddaughters Anne and Darcy and loved nieces and nephews, died peacefully January 13, 2011 at Fillmore Pond in Bennington, Vermont. Born in New Brunswick, NJ, she grew up in Coney Island, Brooklyn, NY and was an
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MISHKIND, DOROTHY

body: The Works Progress Administration kept artists employed during the Great Depression, teaching the masses. In New York City about 50,000 people a week, mostly children, took free painting and drawing classes at community centers. The young artists captured details of their daily lives, like rivets on subway cars and filigree brackets on
title: ANTIQUES; 1930s Children's Art On Display in SoHo

body: There was barely any nod to Manhattan. Nor any mention of the economic virtues of Wall Street, or much talk about national politics. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought on Wednesday to shore up his relationship with his constituents and make the case that he was still fully engaged in his third term. In a speech notable for what was not said, Mr.
title: Mayor Focuses on Small Things in His State of City Speech

body: From where I am sitting, writing this review, in a cafe in the white-hot center of brownstone Brooklyn, the phrase ''Brooklyn Kinda Love'' has a connotation very different from the one that Playboy TV executives intended when they created a series bearing that name. If I were to ask the woman with the stroller seated across from me or, a bit
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; Don't Expect References to Literary Giants

body: As a lifelong resident of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Gary Atlas would always enjoy seeing the robust old Russians marching up the beach, dripping and content after a frigid dip in the wintry ocean. So in September 2007, while unemployed and tending to his mother, Enid, who was dying of emphysema, Mr. Atlas sought relief from depression by running on
title: SWEAT; Workout for a World of Grief

body: Emily Rebecca Rubinstein and Dr. Igor Zilberman were married Saturday evening at Gurney's Inn in Montauk, N.Y. Rabbi Steven D. Burton officiated. Ms. Rubinstein, 27, is keeping her name. She is an epidemiologist now working as a volunteer with the International Center for AIDS Care and Treatment Program at Columbia University. Until the end of
title: Emily Rubinstein, Igor Zilberman

body: In August 2009, a New York Police Department panel, after reviewing evidence and interviews with police officers, school safety agents and a civilian witness, signed off on a decision in the fatal police shooting of a day laborer nine months earlier: Officer Dawn Ortiz's use of deadly physical force was ''within department guidelines.'' The dead
title: Why 2 Findings Conflict In Fatal Police Shooting

body: RUBIN--Joseph, C.P.A.,on January 2, 2011, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of Larry and Jonathan. Cherished grandfather. Devoted brother. Services Wednesday 10am at Sherman Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths RUBIN, JOSEPH, C.P.A.

body: Two New York police officers cleared of department violations in a 2008 fatal shooting of a man in Coney Island will now face a disciplinary trial later this month over their decision-making in the moments before the shooting. A police advisory panel in August 2009 initially determined that Officer Dawn Ortiz did not violate department guidelines
title: 2 Officers Face Sanctions on Tactics in a 2008 Shooting
